isis.stitle: Recall 99502 - Windshield Wiper Linkage on 5000 and 9000 Series

recall.subject: Windshield Wiper Linkage on 5000 and 9000 Series

defect.para: The knurled pivot shaft (which operates the windshield wiper arm) is welded to a lever, which connects to linkage from the wiper motor. The weld at the pivot shaft to lever may fail. This failure can occur on either the right or left side causing the wiper arm to be inoperative for that side. Should one side fail, the other side would still be operational. Should a failure occur during inclement weather on the driver's side with the vehicle in motion, the operator's vision would be partially obscured which could, under certain circumstances, cause a vehicular accident, resulting in personal injury, property damage, or both.

Navistar will notify owners of this campaign on their vehicles. A listing of owner names and addresses has been furnished to the involved dealers to enable dealers to follow up with owners to have the vehicles corrected. You must limit the use of this listing to this campaign since the list may contain information obtained from state motor vehicle registration records and the use of such motor vehicle registration data for purposes other than this campaign is a violation of law in several states.

svcproc.title: STALL TEST

note.para: DO NOT PERFORM THE FOLLOWING STALL TEST ON A CUSTOMER'S VEHICLE UNLESS YOU HAVE 2 KITS IN STOCK (PART NUMBER 8900067R91). REPAIR PARTS MUST BE ON HAND TO REPAIR THE VEHICLE SHOULD A PART FAIL DURING THE STALL TEST.

svcproc.para: This is a test to cause failure of weak suspect welds. Do not restrain both arms at the same time. Follow the instructions below.

step1.para: Restrain the left wiper arm at the point of wiper blade attachment. Do not restrain the wiper blade assembly. Operate the wiper switch for 5 seconds in the low speed position and then return the switch to the off position. Remove the wiper arm restraint.
Repeat step one above on the right side. Perform the test one side at a time.
Cycle the wipers on low for 5 seconds and then on high for 5 seconds. Should one or both of the wiper arms not cycle properly, follow the replacement procedure below for the defective side(s).

note.para: A repair kit should be installed ONLY IF a wiper arm fails the stall test. A failed test results in an inoperative wiper arm due to a broken weld at the pivot shaft.

step1.para: Remove the wiper arm from the knurled pivot shaft.
Remove 4 screws from the pivot shaft housing and dislodge it from the cowl. Retain the screws for the new pivot shaft housing.
Secure the wiper motor linkage arm to keep it from falling into the cowl.
Remove the e-clip and washer securing the wiper motor linkage to the lever connected to the pivot shaft.
Disconnect the washer hose and remove the pivot shaft, housing, and gasket.
Connect the washer hose to the new pivot shaft housing.
Install the washer and e-clip securing the wiper motor linkage to the lever connected to the pivot shaft.
Place the pivot housing in position with the new gasket in place and secure it with 4 screws.
Position and install the wiper arm.
Repeat the procedure for the opposite side ONLY IF both arms fail the stall test.
Cycle the wipers and adjust the wipe pattern if required.

partsinfo.para: Since less than 30% of the vehicles are expected to need one part kit, do not order a kit for more than 30% of your total number of vehicles involved.

entry.para: Kit, Wiper Pivot Housing/Lever (Kit includes pivot housing/lever, gasket, washer and e-clip)
Perform Stall Test Only on both wiper arms.
Perform Stall Test and replace one Pivot Housing Assembly.
Perform Stall Test and replace two Pivot Housing Assemblies.

responuscan.para:
Proceed immediately to make necessary correction to units in inventory. All inventory vehicles subject to this recall campaign must be corrected prior to sale, transfer or delivery.
If vehicles have been sold or transferred and you are in receipt of Customer Notification Letters and Authorization for Recall Service cards for those vehicles, transfer location or customer must be notified from your dealer location.
Dealers must correct all vehicles subject to this campaign at no charge to the owner, regardless of mileage, age of vehicle, or ownership, from this time forward.

The National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act, as amended, provides that each vehicle that is subject to a vehicle recall campaign must be adequately repaired within a reasonable time after the owner has tendered it for repair. A failure to adequately repair within 60 days after a tender of a vehicle is prima facie evidence of failure to repair within a reasonable time. If the condition is not adequately repaired within 60 days, the owner may be entitled to replacement with an identical or reasonable equivalent vehicle at no charge, or to a refund of the purchase price less a reasonable allowance for depreciation.

In order to avoid having to replace an owner's vehicle or refund the purchase price, every effort must be made to promptly schedule an appointment with each owner to repair their vehicle as soon as possible.
